title: The surreal health benefits of a Spanish wine bath treatment
text:
Lee Tran Lam Sep 5, 2019 — 10.13am Share

Stepping into a bath full of merlot might seem like a surreal experience, but it’s a regular activity in Peralada, a medieval Spanish village with a long history of wine-making – and fittingly, just a short drive from Salvador Dali’s home town of Figueres (or a two-hour trip north-east from Barcelona if you’re armed with a Eurail pass).

The earliest hangovers in the region date back to the sixth century BC, when Greeks arrived in nearby Empuries and started tending vines. In the Middle Ages, Carmelite monks operating from the 14th-century castle that’s still Peralada’s most famous landmark stocked their cellars with booze made from neighbouring vineyards.

Today, robes and sandals are no longer part of the vintner uniform but bottles of grenache, syrah and more still come out of the Castillo de Peralada, using grapes grown in the region: on the red clay slopes of Garriguella, in the sandy soil of Pont de Molins, or along the vine-dense, slate-heavy foothills of the Pyrenees. And if any are left over, there’s always the Hotel Peralada’s wine spa.

Aside from its wine treatments, Hotel Peralada also boasts a golf course on its grounds.

Here, the polyphenol-rich grape matter is repurposed into beauty products for treatments such as grape-seed peels, red-wine body wraps and vineyard “flower” facials, while the vintages themselves are poured into the hotel’s special wine bath and wine Jacuzzi.

Dipping into a tub of red isn’t a new phenomenon. It’s said that Cleopatra enjoyed wine baths and was convinced the practice had a moisturising effect. During the Renaissance, women thought the ritual would soften their skin. At Japan’s “hot springs amusement park” in Hakone, there’s a red-wine onsen that’s filled by a giant novelty-sized wine bottle, while France’s Chateau Smith Haut Lafitte vineyard features vine-leaf baths and has become ground zero for Mathilde Thomas’ international empire of Caudalie “vinotherapy” beauty spas.

So Hotel Peralada doesn’t have a monopoly on wine baths and treatments, but people still travel long distances to sink into its Jacuzzi bubbling with merlot.

Hotel Peralada’s indoor pool.

The resort’s spa manager, Cristina Tincu, is fluent in French, as most of her clients cross the nearby French-Spanish border to use the spa. Treatments are inspired by the ancient Romans, who were known to use grape must (juice) in massages and maintained vintner traditions after settling in the region.

“We have a lot of vineyards here,” Tincu says, so repurposing excess wine and its by-products for bathing and beauty rituals makes sense. “If we think about the composition of the wine, you have a lot of properties that are also cleansing.” Resveratrol (an antioxidant that’s found in red grape skins, extracts and seeds) has been touted for its health benefits, with the Journal of Drugs in Dermatology citing its potential for treating ageing skin.
description: Near the birthplace of Salvador Dali in Catalonia, Hotel Peralada offers merlot shampoo, grape-seed peels – and a Jacuzzi filled with litres of red.
